metadata.title: Designing a multi-epitope peptide-based vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 Scientist C -Centre for DNA Taxonomy & Coordinator -Centre for Forensic Sciences

abstract.text: 14 COVID-19 pandemic has resulted so far 14,395,16 confirmed cases with 85,711 deaths from the 15 212 countries, or territories. Due to multifacet issues and challenges in implementation of the 16 safety & preventive measures, inconsistent coordination between societies-governments and 17 most importanly lack of specific vaccine to SARS-CoV-2, the spread of Wuhan originated virus 18 is still uprising after taking a heavy toll on human life. In the present study, we mapped several 19 immunogenic epitopes (B-cell, T-cell, and IFN-gamma) over the entire structural proteins of 20 SARS-CoV-2 and by applying various computational and immunoinformatics approaches, we 21 designed a multi-epitope peptide based vaccine that predicted high immunogenic response in the 22 largest proportion of world's human population. To ensure high expression of the recombinant 23 vaccine in E. coli, codon optimization and in-silico cloning were also carried out. The designed 24 vaccine with high molecular affinity to TLR3 and TLR4, was found capable to initiate effective 25 innate and adaptive immune response. The immune simulation also suggested uprising high 26 levels of both B-cell and T-cell mediated immunity which on subsequent exposure cleared 27 antigen from the system. The proposed vaccine found promising by yielding desired results and 28 hence, should be tested by practical experimentations for its functioning and efficacy to 29 neutralize SARS-CoV-2.

The identified epitopes 123 were scrutinized based on the consensus score i.e. ≤2 and only those epitopes were considered as 124 strong binders and selected for further analysis which were predicted by more than one allele of 125 both the method used.

Helper T-cell (HTL) epitopes 127 Fifteen residue long HTL epitopes recognized by HLA Class II DRB1 alleles were predicted 128 using Net MHC II pan 3.2 server [35] . The thresholds for strong binder and weak binder were set 129 as default. Further another set of HTL epitopes of 15 residues length recognized by HLA DR 130 alleles were identified using the consensus method as implemented in the IEDB server [34] The 131 epitopes with a percentile rank of ≤2 and predicted by more than one allele of both the methods 132 were considered as a strong binder and scrutinized for further analysis. 134 Considering the fact that epitopes with affinity for multiple HLA alleles tend to induce relatively 135 more immune response in the host cell, we scrutinized overlapping epitopes with affinity to both 136 HLA class I and class II alleles for immunogenicity and allergen prediction using VaxiJen v2.0 were predicted using Ellipro server [38] . The prediction parameters like Minimum score and 146 Maximum distance (Anstrom) were set as 0.8 and 6, respectively. 148 Since, IFN gamma is the signature cytokine of both the innate and adaptive immune system and 149 epitopes with potency to induce IFN gamma could boost the immunogenic capacity of any 150 vaccine. Thus, IFN gamma epitopes were predicted for each structural protein by the IFNepitope 151 server [39] .

Predicted T-cell and B-cell epitopes were submitted to the IEDB conservancy analys is tool [40] 155 to identify the degree of conservancy in the structural protein sequences and the epitopes with 156 100% conservancy were selected for further analysis.

Population coverage and autoimmunity identification 158 Immunogenetic response of human population towards the selected overlapping CTL and HTL 159 epitopes against their respective HLA genotype frequencies was predicted using IEDB 160 population coverage analysis tool [41] . Those epitopes exhibiting 50% or more population 161 coverage were scrutinized and to red uce the probability of autoimmunity, all the selected 162 epitopes were subjected to BlastP search analysis against the Human proteome. Epitopes
showing similarity to any human protein were excluded from the further analysis.

Inte raction analysis of epitopes and their HLA alleles 165 The sequence of scrutinized epitopes was submitted to an online server PEPFOLD 3 [42] for 3D 166 structure modeling. The structure of the most common HLA alleles i.e. HLA-DRB1 *01:01 167 (HLA class II) and HLA-A* 02:01 (HLA class I) in human population were retrieved from 168 Protein data bank (PDB) with a PDB ID of 2g9h and 1QEW. Any ligand associated with the 169 HLA allele's structure was removed and energyminimization was carried out. Thereafter, the 170 modeled epitopes were docked with the corresponding HLA allele using a web server Patchdock

[43], to study the interaction pattern of receptor and ligand. The parameters like clustering 172 RMSD value and the complex type was kept as 0.4 and default. The result obtained from 173 Patchdock was forwarded to the Firedock server [44] for the refinement of the best 10 models.
Based on Global energy value, the complex with the lowest global energy was scrutinized and 175 the corresponding CTL and HTL epitopes were selected for the final vaccine construct.
Construction and quality control of final multi-epitope vaccine 177 For the construction of a multi-epitope vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, we followed Chauhan et 178 al.

[23] with some modifications. The epitopes were finally selected based on meeting the 179 following criteria: 1). epitopes must be immunogenic, non-allergic and overlapping with affinity 180 to both HLA class I and class II alleles; 2).epitopes must be capable to activate both CTL and 181 HTL cells and must have a minimum 50% of the population coverage; 3).epitopes should not be 182 overlapping with any human gene and the predicted B-Cell epitopes should overlap with 183 finalized CTL and HTL epitopes and should be present on the surface of the target protein.

FIGREF1.text: Identification of Continuous and Discontinuous B-cell epitopes140 B-cell epitopes are short amino acid sequences recognized by the surface-bound receptors of B-141 lymphocyte. Their identification plays a major role in vaccine designing, and thus two types-142 Continuous and Discontinuous B-cell epitopes were predicted over the corresponding structural 143 protein sequences. The continuous B-cell epitopes, present on the surface of proteins, were 144 predicted using BCpred 2.0 [37] server and the discontinuous epitopes which were fairly large 145

FIGREF2.text: Antigenicity, alle rgenicity and physioche mical properties of vaccine190    The antigenicity of the proposed vaccine was predicted using VaxiJen v2.0 server [24] a nd191 allergenicity was predicted using Allertop v.2.0 prediction tool [36]. The physicochemical 192 property of the designed vaccine was predicted by submitting the final sequence of the vaccine to 193 the Expasy Protpram online server [25]. 194 Prediction of secondary structure 195 The secondary structure of the constructed vaccine was predicted using the SOPMA tool [26]. 196 With the input of vaccine sequence and output width 70, the parameters like the number of 197 conformational states, similarity threshold, and window width were set as 4 (Helix, Sheet, Turn, 198 Coil), 8 and 17.

FIGREF3.text: Modeling, refinement, and validation of vaccine construct200    The final model of the constructed vaccine was prepared using a homology modeling tool201 SPARKS-X [45]. Among the top 10 predicted models, the model with the highest Z-score was 202 selected and subjected for refinement using the Galaxy refine server [30]. Among all the 203 refinement tools, Galaxy refine is one of the most efficient server according to CASP10 204 evaluation. Then after, we utilized ProSA-webtool [46] to assess the overall and local quality of 205 the predicted model based on the Z-score. If the Z-score lies outside the range of native protein 206 of similar size, a chance of error increases in the predicted structure. Further to check the overall 207 quality of the refined structure of vaccine, Ramachandran plot analysis was carried out using the 208 RAMPAGE server [31]. The final model of the vaccine construct was visualized using Chimera 209 1.10.1 visulaization system [32].

FIGREF4.text: Discontinuous B-cell epitopes in the vaccine construct were predicted using 212 BCpred 2.0 [37] and IEDB server [34], respectively. For effective designing of vaccine, the 213 constructed vaccine should posses' B-cell epitopes for potential enhancement of immunogenic 214 reactions. Molecular docking of constructed vaccine with TLR3 and TLR4 receptor 216 The 3D structures of human TLR3 and TLR4 were retrieved from protein data bank (PDB ID: 217 2A0Z and 2z63). Any ligand attached to the retrieved structures was removed and the receptor 218 was subjected for model refinement using Galaxy refine server [30]. Molecular docking analysis 219 was performed using the Cluspro v.2 protein-protein docking server [47] to analyze the 220 interaction pattern of vaccine with TLR3 and TLR4. The server provides cluster scores based on 221 rigid docking by sampling billions of conformation, pairwise RMSD energy minimization. Based 222 on the lowest energy weight score and members, the final vaccine-TLR3 complex and TLR4 223 complex model was selected and visualized using Chimera 1.10.1 visulaization system [32] .

FIGREF5.text: In silico cloning and vaccine optimization225 Efficiency of the multi-epitope vaccine construct in cloning and expression is of the utmost 226 importance for vaccine designing. The final multi-epitope vaccine construct was submitted to the 227 Java Codon Adaptation Tool (JCat) [48], where codon optimization was performed in E. coli 228 strain K12. In addition to this, the parameters like Avoid rho-independent transcription 229 terminators, Avoid prokaryotic ribosome binding sites, Avoid Cleavage Sites of Restriction 230 Enzymes were selected for the final submission. The output of the JCat tool provided CAI value 231 and GC content of the optimized sequence. Ideally, the CAI value should be greater than 0.8 or 232 nearer to 1 [49], and the GC content should be in a range of 30 to 70% [50] to ensure that the 233 vaccine has potential translation, stability and transcription efficiency. Further, an in silico 234 cloning of a multi-epitope vaccine construct in E. coli pET-28(+) vector was performed using 235 the SnapGene 4.2 tool [51]. 236 Immune simulations of vaccine construct 237 To characterize the real-life immunogenic profiles and immune response of the multi-epitope 238 vaccine, C-ImmSim server [52] was utilized. Position-specific scoring matrix (PSSM) and 239 machine learning are the two methods, based on which C-ImmSim predicts immune epitopes and 240 immune interactions. It simultaneously simulates three different anatomical regions of mammals, 241 i.e. Bone marrow, Thymus and tertiary lymphatic organs. To conduct the immune simulation, 242 three injections at an interval of four weeks were administered with 1000 vaccine molecules per 243 injection. The parameters like Random seed, simulation volume, and simulation step were kept 244 as 12345, 10µl and 1050. Several studies suggested that the minimum interval between two 245 injections should be kept four weeks and thus the time steps followed for three injections were 1, 84 and 168 where each time step is equal to 8 hours of real-life [53]. Since, several patients 247 wordwide got recurrent infection of SARS-CoV-2, 12 consecutive injections were administered 248 four weeks apart for the assessment of after effects of vaccine exposure on SARStarget structural protein sequences, i.e. Surface, Membrane, Envelop and 252 Nucleocapsid proteins from the whole-genome of SARS-CoV-2, 29903 bp ss-RNA (GenBank: 253 MN908947.3). Antigenicity prediction from the structural protein sequences revealed that 254 Envelop proteins has the highest antigenicity score 0.6025, followed by Membrane, 255 Nucleocapsid and Surface protein (table 1). 256 Physioche mical and secondary structural prope rties 257 Theoretical estimates of isoelectric point (PI) suggested that all the structural proteins were basic 258 in nature and their predicted instability indices were below 40 indicating their stable nature 259 except the Nucleocapsid protein with an instability index of 55.09 (table S1). The predicted 260 secondary structure characteristics of all the structural proteins showed varaible percentage of 261 Alpha Helix, Extended Strand, Beta Turn and Random Coil(table S2).

With these criteria, five epitopes were obtained in Surface protein, three in 283 Nucleocapsid and one in Membrane protein (table S12). No epitope with such criteria was 284 identified in Envelop protein. Further, one discontinuous epitope in Envelop protein, seven in 285 Nucleocapsid, nine in Surface and four discontinuous epitopes were predicted in Membrane 286 protein (table S13). 287 Identification of IFN-gamma epitopes 288 The server IFNepitope predicted eight epitopes in Envelop protein, 39 in Membrane, 66 in 289 Nucleocapsid and 281 in Surface protein. Based on antigenicity and non-allergenicity, eight 290 epitopes were scrutinized in Envelop protein, 13 in Membrane, 43 in Nucleocapsid and 81 in 291 Surface protein. To obtain the highest immunogenicity and reduce the overload of epitopes in 292 vaccine construct, we selected one epitope from each protein with the highest antigenicity score 293 and non-allergenicity (table S14). 294 Characterization of predicted epitopes 295 Conservation analysis, Population coverage, and autoimmunity identification 296 The conservation prediction resulted that all the selected T cell and B cell epitopes were 100% 297 conserved among the target structural proteins and population coverage prediction showed that 298 five epitopes in Envelop protein, two in Membrane, two in Nucleocapsid and six epitopes in 299 Surface protein covered more than 50% of worldwide population. No selected epitope with 300 >50% population coverage showed homology with any human protein. Thus, altogether 30 301 epitopes, 15 each of CTL and HTL, met the above criteria were processed for the interaction 302 analysis with the commonly occurring HLA alleles in the Human population(table S15).

FIGREF11.text: Inte raction analysis of epitopes and their HLA allelesMolecular interaction analysis of each selected CTL and HTL epitopes with their respective 305 HLA alleles resulted in 10 predicted docked complex. Each complex showed different Global 306 energy value. Out of the characterized 30 epitopes, the epitopes with highest negative value of 307 Global energy (set threshold -40) were considered as effectively interacting epitopes with the 308 corresponding HLA allele, and thus selected for final vaccine construct (table 2). This resulted in 309 two CTL and HTL epitopes in Envelop protein, one in Membrane, two in Nuc leocapsid and two 310 in Surface protein. For an ideal vaccine, the epitopes included should have potential affinity 311 towards their respective alleles and thus greater the interaction between epitopes and their alleles, 312 more is the affinity.

FIGREF14.text: Evaluation of antigenicity, allergenicity, physioche mical properties and secondary 321 structure of the vaccine construct322    The multi-epitope vaccine construct found to be immunogenic (Ag score-0.627), non-allergic 323 with 45.131 KDa predicted molecular weight. The pred iction suggested that vaccine construct324 was stable and basic in nature with instability index 23.46 and theoretical PI 9.01. The half-life 325 of the vaccine in mammalian reticulocytes (in vitro) was 30 hrs, while it was about 20 hrs in 326 yeast (in-vivo) and 10 hrs in E. coli (in vivo). 327 The predicted secondary structure of the vaccine constructed consisted 42.33% alpha-helix, 328 22.09% extended strand, 4.42% beta-turn and 31.16% random coil. 329 Modeling, refinement, and validation of vaccine construct 330 Of the top 10 predicted models, the model with the Z-score of 7.61 with template 1dd3A was 331 selected for refinement. The ProSA-web tool assessed the overall and local quality of the refined 332 model with a Z-score of -0.47 which was close to the range of native protein of similar size 333 (figure 3). Further, the Ramachandran plot analysis revealed 92% of residues in the favored region, 6.1% in the allowed region and 1.9% outliers. This signified that the quality of the 335 predicted vaccine construct was adequate for further analysis. 336 Prediction of Continuous and Discontinuous epitopes 337 BCpred 2.0 server predicted four continuous epitopes i.e. AKILKEKYGLD, 338 EILDKSKEKTSFD, LKESKDLV and VPKHLKKGLSKEEAESLKKQLEEV on the surface of 339 predicted vaccine (figure S2), while IEDB predicted six discontinuous epitopes (figure S3) with 340 a score higher than 0.8

FIGREF16.text: TLR3 complex and model number 1 in TLR4 complex were selected as a best-345 docked complex with the lowest energy score of -1199.1 with 46 members (TLR3) and lowest 346 energy score of -1229.9 with 79 members (TLR4). This signifies potential molecular interaction 347 between predicted vaccine construct with TLR3 and TLR 4 receptors (figure 4).348 In silico cloning and vaccine optimization 349 The Java Codon Adaptation Tool optimized the codon usage o f the vaccine and produced an 350 optimized codon sequence of length 1290 nucleotides. The CAI value of optimized sequences 351 was 0.95, close to 1 and the GC content was found to be 54.41 %, fall between the range of 30 to 352 70%. Therefore, the adaptation was satisfactory indicating potential expression of vaccine 353 construct in host E.coli. Later on, the restriction sequence of Xho I and Not I restriction enzymes 354 were added to N and C terminal of adapted codon sequence. Further, the adapted sequence was 355 also cloned in pET-28(+) vector using SnapGene tool (figure 5).356 Immune simulations of vaccine construct 357 C-ImmSim server-generated immune response was consistent with the actual immune response 358 as depicted by the results (figure 6 and S4). The primary response was generated as marked by 359 the increase in the level of IgM. Similarly, the secondary response was characterized by an 360 increased level of IgM+IgG, IgG1+IgG2, IgG1, IgG2, and B-cell populations. On the subsequent 361 exposure of vaccine, a decrease in the level of antigens was observed indicating the development 362 of immunogenic response in the form of immune memory. Both the T cell populations i.e. CTL and HTL developed increased response corresponding to the memory cells signifying the 364 immunogenicity of T cell epitopes included in the vaccine construct. Increased activity of 365 macrophages was also observed at each exposure, whereas the activity of NK cells was observed 366 consistent throughout the period. A significant increase in the level of IFN gamma, IL-10, IL-23, 367 and IL-12 was also observed at subsequent exposure (figure 6). After the repeated exposure of 368 vaccine construct through 12 injections after a regular interval, a remarkable increase in the 369 level of IgM+IgG, IgG1+IgG2. Though, IgG1 increased slightly but IgM and IgG2 increased 370 consistently. A surge in the memory corresponding to B cell and T cells was observed 371 throughout the exposure while the level of IFN gamma was consistently high from first to last 372 exposure (figure S4). This signifies that the vaccine proposed in this study has generated a strong 373 immune response in case of short exposure and immunity increases even on subsequent repeated 374 exposure. 375 Discussion 376 The recent outbreak of SARS-CoV-2 in Wuhan city of China raised several questions regarding 377 the susceptibility of Humans against these novel pathogens. As predicted earlier about the re-378 emergence of novel variants of SARS-CoV [54], SARS-CoV-2 proved to be more lethal as 379 compared to the previous variants in terms of wide spread of virus in a short period of time. This 380 escalated rate of transmission initiated a pursuit for a vaccine development against SARS-CoV-381 2, which is currently a worldwide pandemic with over 1.43 million cases and 85, 711 deaths [1]. 382 With strict and comprehensive measures, vaccine development and its application could play a 383 key role in eliminating the virus from the Human population or to restrain the spread among 384 individuals and different populations. Thus several efforts are being made to address the 385 challenge that appeared in the current scenario with appreciable advancements in the 386 understanding of virus biology and its etiology. The lack of knowledge regarding the response of 387 the immune system against viral infection is one of the major limitations in the path of vaccine 388 development for SARS-CoV-2. 389 This study is the piolt attempt in describing the potential immunogenic target over the structural 390 proteins and proposes a novel multi-epitope vaccine construct, by providing new rays of hope in 391 the initial phase of vaccine development. Certain criteria like poor antigenicity, allergenicity, low 392 affinity towards the immune cells, autoimmunity and oversize that could influence the effectiveness, have been evaluated on the proposed vaccine construct following various 394 computational and immunoinformatics approach. The retrieved structural proteins and their 395 antigenicity score suggested that the Envelop protein is the most potent protein to generate 396 immune response considering its role in viral assembly. Since, immunity against any pathogen is 397 prominently dependent, how it gets recognized by B cells and T cells. We identified epitopes 398 corresponding to B cells and T cells in each structural protein so that both humoral and cellular 399 immunity can be induced with the exposure of vaccine construct. The proposed vaccine construct 400 is designed based on the epitopes that have been selected with the most robust criteria,e.g. their 401 nature of antigenic, non-allergic, 100% conserved among the target proteins, their affinity for 402 multiple alleles, no homology with any of the human proteins, their worldwide coverage of 403 human population (>50% of worldwide population covered) and effective molecular interaction 404 with their respective HLA alleles. Further,, IFN gamma epitopes which are equally effective in 405 immune regulatory, antiviral and antitumor activities, the final vaccine construct was designed 406 with also due considering of the IFN gamma epitopes to increase the immune recognition ability. 407 The designed vaccine of 430 amino acid residues has a molecular weight of 45.131K Da, also 408 falls in the defined range of average molecular weight of a mullti-epitope vaccine. The instability 409 index and theoretical PI also suggested that the vaccine is stable and basic in nature and the 410 estimated half-life suggested that the recognized peptide does not possess a short half-life and 411 would remain viable for a span adequate to generate a potential immune response. Vaccine 412 model refinement and validation indicated that quality of the predicted model was good as more 413 than 90% residues were in the favored region [55]. The B-cell continuous epitopes predicted 414 over the surface of the vaccine suggested that the vaccine is capable to get recognized by B-cells 415 indicating its effectiveness. TLR 3 and TLR 4 have proven recognition capability in both SARS-416 CoV and MERSCoV. Considering the similar genome characterization of SARS-CoV and 417 SARS-CoV-2, the molecular interaction of vaccine with TLR 3 and TLR 4 through docking 418 analysis suggested that the constructed vaccine has a significant affinity towa rds the toll-like 419 receptors to act as sensor for recognizing molecular patterns of pathogen and initiating immune 420 response. Thus the vaccine TLR complex is capable of generating an effective innate immune 421 response against SARS-CoV-2. Further, Codon adaptation improved the expression of the 422 recombinant vaccine in E coli. Strain K12 with significant codon adaptation index and GC 423 content indicating elevated expression level. After successful cloning of the recombinant vaccine in the pET-28(+) vector, the simulation based generated immune response suggested that the 425 primary and secondary immune response will be coherent with the actual expected response. 426 Subsequent exposure for three injections indicated the potential capability of vaccine for 427 generating memory cells and a higher probability of significant immune response on later 428 exposure to coronavirus. The consistent high level of IFN gamma also supported the activation 429 of humoral immunity. To understand the immunogenic potential of vaccine, repeated exposure in 430 the form of 12 injections was administered and the result suggested the consistent generation of a 431 strong immune response. With all these immunoinformatics approaches, the vaccine designed 432 against SARS-CoV-2 showed promising results in inducing immune response. 433 Without proper control methods or vaccines, it is difficult to curb coronavirus pandemic given 434 the current situation. However, several medications have been tested against SARS-CoV-2, but 435 none of them showed complete effectiveness. In this study, a vaccinomics approach was carried 436 out to design a multi-epitope vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 using several in silico and 437 immunoinformatic approaches. Based on the computational and immunoinformatics approaches, 438 we propose that the designed vaccine has all the potential to induce both the innate and adaptive 439 immune systems and can neutralize the SARS-CoV-2, and therefore, an experimental validation 440 of the designed vaccine must be undertaken by the professional for reaching a conclusion for its 441 safety, efficacy and success. 442 Acknowledge ments 443 We thank Zoological Survey of India, Kolkata for providing access to the computational support, 444 working space and facilities to undertake the present study. 16.
